Yes @dlaboss let me try it and see if I can resolve it.

The HttpServerSample mods weren't the ones inducing the test problem.  It seemed to be the mods to ConsoleJobServlet.  I _suspect_ that the changes to _any_ of the `console/servlet` files will run into this problem.  So you'll have to undo your changes to those while @home4slc investigates that.
See QUARKS-147 (adaptable TWindow width) for motivation for the PeriodicMXBean=>PeriodMXBean change and TStream.TYPE and change in registration.

I think the general case is that  the "concurrent operations" are a pipeline of arbitrary operations, not a single function, though then there are potential issues with missing or extra tuples.

Need to define what happens with missing tuples, i.e. a mapper returns null.

Do the checks rerun if they fail? I just ran the same build command: 

ant -Dquarks.build.ci=true -lib /usr/share/java/junit4.jar -lib jacoco-0.7.5/lib clean all test release

And it successfully built on my machine. I think it may have started building and I added several commits mid build? Not sure if that would be a problem...

Good Day @home4slc

Nah, if the "build" fails it doesn't run again until another commit is added or you close/reopen the PR.
In this case one of the WebSocketClient connector tests failed.  This has been happening intermittently -  QUARKS-122.

Yeah, the next commit will add a 2nd "stream based" concurrent() method for feedback.  At least with this initial version, each pipeline MUST return exactly one result tuple for an input tuple.  (can offer alternatives later if needed).

I'll also update the "function based" concurrentMap() to indicate that mappers MUST return non-null.  (same "can do more later if needed").

The pipeline comment also made me think that users of the "function based" concurrentMap() would find it convenient if Quarks functions supported Java8 style function composition - e.g., `java.util.Function.andThen()`.  Thoughts on that?  I can create a Jira to track that.
I'm sorry. miss cliicked

I'm going to merge this now.
@saurabhjinturkar, can you start a new branch/PR and complete converting the console code now that  the fix for QUARKS-157 has been delivered?
Thanks @dlaboss. I will update console part and generate a new pull request.

I'm posting tests for the concurrentMap() and concurrent() as well as initial implementations.  The initial implementations explore what it would be like with no new oplets.  Comments on those welcome.  Real barrier is next.

This is all set for final review.

Q: are things in the "best" packages?

These API enhancements were made:
- Added PlumbingStreams.concurrent()
- Added PlumbingStreams.concurrentMap()
- Added PlumbingStreams.barrier()
- Added PlumbingStreams.isolate(stream, queueCapacity) (and tweaked Isolate)
- Added TStream.fanin()
- Added quarks.oplet.core.FanIn
- Adjusted Union: isa FanIn
- Added quarks.oplet.plumbing.Barrier (isa FanIn)
- Added tests for concurrent() (implicitly barrier()/Barrier/FanIn)

TODO: add explicit test for barrier()
@ddebrunner +1 on the API changes noted above?

I have added functionality to support postJson() method. I added a method to add body to HTTP requests. Could you please review the code? I will fix review comments and failing build together.

Hi @dlaboss,
Regarding build failure, it seems there is some issue with SSL and certs. I checked  logs for failed build of #116. I found that its the same reason as for #106. Could you please guide on this?

To build think the sequence was:

```
# Build the api code using gradle
gradle
# Build the rest of the code using ant
ant
```

sorry for the delay...

Hi @dlaboss, It's final exam week for me. Sorry for the delay in fixing review comments.
no worries. hope things go well for you!
Do I need to add the new test classes to a test suite file somewhere?

Any test in a test directory with name XXXTest.java will be picked up automatically.

You should run the test suite before any commit, it does seem the new tests are failing.

There is one test failing: `FileStreamsTextFileWriterGlobalTest.testRetainAggSizeBased` due to: `java.lang.AssertionError:  [] expected:<2> but was:<0>`

It fails in my local testing environment as well. Something interesting: if I change the `globalStr` string to just a single character (e.g., `九` or `Θ`), I get 1 element instead of 0: `[/var/folders/sf/blbx3s152dn2mdhppv9sg3xc0000gn/T/test14407282066706266234txt_201605147_152303_3] expected:<2> but was:<1>`

If I change the `globalStr` string to `123456789` (the original string), then the test passes, which leads me to conclude that the issue is not in the test code.

Any ideas where the error might be?

I'm guessing the computation of aggregateFileSize is the problem - it's computing characters while the retention "file size" is in bytes.

Try changing `long aggregateFileSize = 2 * (("1-"+getStr()).length() + 1/*eol*/);`
to `... = 2 * (("1-"+getStr()).getBytes().length + 1/*eol*/);`

I'm assuming it's NOT the `assertEquals(2, expResults.size());` that's the one being triggered.
@dlaboss That was it, thank you! Test is passing now.
The build failed because a HTTP connector test failed, which this PR should not affect. Is there a way to run the Travis build again?
to rerun, close and reopen the PR.

Changing to WIP until concerns raised in QUARKS-195 are resolved.

I didn't see any updates to DEVELOPMENT.md to tell folks how to build.

If this is merged to master, what's the resulting state of the build, do I need to use ant and gradle, can I continue to build to support Android, can I still build a release?

Or was this meant to be a pull request to a gradle branch?

This PR is initially for discussion about how to proceed. As I mentioned more work is needed, that I can purse, if we agree to go this route. That work will of course need to include updated to docs like DEVELOPMENT.md  and also .travis.yml.

This PR is not against the gradle branch. I started fresh from master as I felt that if we move to a gradle build, we should do things the gradle way (e.g. jars in build/libs) rather than just replace ant with gradle and continue to use the ant builds places for class file, jar files, etc. One of the points of having a gradle build is that gradle knowledgeable engineers can understand the build quickly. Having non-standard places for outputs go against that. 

This branch can be merged to master with no affect on the ant build since this gradle build puts it output in gradle standard places which are different than the places the ant build uses. So we could merge this into master and then continue to improve the gradle build while the ant build continues to function. Then when the gradle build is at functional parity, we can remove the ant build.
@bjhargrave FYI - the convention is to prefix the pull request with `[WIP]` to indicate work-in-progress

> @bjhargrave FYI - the convention is to prefix the pull request with [WIP] to indicate work-in-progress

Fixed. Thanks.
This is awesome!  I'm looking it over/learning and giving it a shot.
The build files look good, simple and clear to understand.

Nice work! It looks very cleanly. I learned a lot in your work!

Could I kindly ask some questions?
1. I agree with your idea that follow the gradle way, such as build/libs. 
   But for make apache distribution(package of jars), I think we need function that copy all the jars to specific directory. How do you think about the need for these function?
2. Unlike the Ant Build, the higher-level jar is generated. Could I delete them?
   (e.g. ant only have quarks.analytics.math3.jar, quarks.analytics.sensors.jar
   However, gradle has a additional empty incubator-quarks.analytics.jar)

And I think there are additional work needed as follow:
(These task is just a simple & repeated work. I can append it)
1. All gradle script should have apache license header
2. Javadoc process is missing. 
3. Update user manual(such as DEVELOPMENT.md)

All built fine and tests passed for me. Ditto for ant build/test in the same repo.  Ditto from Eclipse. So, it seems like this can be merged w/o any ill effects to the existing mechanisms.

BJ, your thoughts re merging this now vs after more work?  Now seems good to me. Maybe capture the known TODO items in the jira so we an track it all?

I was looking at the gradle generated test reports (.../build/reports/tests/index.html).  Can a top-level summary page be generated?  OK to put that as one of the TODOs :-)

But yes we do need a clean run to be sure.  Not sure why it one was forced to look at the raw log this time.

The httpbin.org tests are among them. :-(

Are we sure this is correct, and that it's not an error in the window library which should be guaranteeing synchronization?
The code in timeBatchEnsureUnique() around line 419 seems to still have synchronization issues in that it could complete before 1000 tuples have been inserted.

Ok - see that making batches synchronized in timeBatchEnsureUnique ensures that the thread running the junit test has visibility for changes made during window processing.

Another approach that would also test the window api would be to synchronize on the partition instance when performing the verification against batches, but as coded is probably how a user would use it.
Closing and will reopen - hopefully it will work now.
Oops, now it is saying I have unmerged commits.  Can someone advise me on what I need to do to reopen the pull request correctly?  Thanks, Susan

Reopen the PR.  If it then says that it can't be merged due to conflicts (some other PR has been merged that changes one or more of the same file as this PR) you need to rebase your PR branch so it's up to date with respect to the master branch... standard github fork-workflow stuff.
